image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from Maryland; born in Annapolis, Md., August 16, 1817; was tutored privately; lived in Alexandria, Va. and Wilmington; returned to Maryland in 1827 with his father, who settled in Anne Arundel County; attended Wilmington College in 1826 and 1827; St. John's College, Annapolis, Md., and Hampden-Sydney College, Virginia; was graduated from Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, in 1837; studied law at the University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Alexandria, Va.; in 1850 moved to Baltimore, Md., where he continued the practice of law and also engaged in literary pursuits; elected as the candidate of the American Party to the Thirty-fourth through Thirty-sixth Congresses (March 4, 1855-March 3, 1861); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1860 to the Thirty-seventh Congress; elected as an Unconditional Unionist to the Thirty-eighth Congress (March 4, 1863-March 3, 1865); chairman, Committee on Foreign Affairs (Thirty-eighth Congress); co-sponsor of the Wade-Davis bill of 1864; was not a candidate for renomination in 1864; died in Baltimore, Md., on December 30, 1865; interment in Greenmount Cemetery.

note.content: Election unsuccessfully contested by Henry P. Brooks.
Election unsuccessfully contested by William G. Harrison.

researchRecord.name: In the John A. J. Creswell Papers, ca. 1819-1885, 8 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Henry Winter Davis. A finding aid is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: In the B. F. Wade Papers, 1832-1881, approximately 3,522 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include H. Winter Davis. A finding aid is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: 1817-1863, 1 box.
researchRecord.description: Manuscript autobiography of Henry Winter Davis covering his early life at Annapolis, Kenyon College, and University of VA. Also a letter from A.Lincoln, Mar. 18, 1863, "not for publication", stressing importance of agreement among those U. S. Representatives supporting the Union, with regard to election of House Speaker.

researchRecord.name: 1862, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Samuel Tyler to Henry Winter Davis written on May 21, 1862. In the letter, Samuel Tyler states his appreciation for Davis's criticism of his work.

researchRecord.name: In the John Reese Kenly Papers, 1865, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Edwin M. Stanton to Henry Winter Davis written on April 8, 1865. In the letter, Edwin Stanton writes that he received Davis's note on Gen. [John R.] Kenly; assignments of command are made by commanding generals & not by War Dept. Edwin Stanton also writes that he will suggest to Gen. Grant his [Stanton's] wish that Kenly be assigned as Davis requests.

researchRecord.name: In the Mercantile Library Association of Baltimore Records, 1839-1873, 3 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The records include a letter from H. Winter Davis to Mr. Green on August 16, 1858.

researchRecord.name: In the Henry Du Pont Papers, 1822-1899, 3 linear feet.
In the Samuel Francis Du Pont Papers, 1812-1865, 50 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Subjects include Henry Winter Davis. The collection also is available on microfilm.
